newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhstan to pay debt with power station stake.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhstan to pay debt with power station stake.

text.p: Kazakhstan intends to transfer a stake in one of its power stations to Russian power company Unified Energy System (UES) to settle its debts, a senior energy ministry official said on Monday.
Department head Yevgeny Ryaskov told Reuters that Kazakhstan would offer UES 30 percent of the Ekibastuz GRES-2 thermal power station, whose total assets are worth $145 million.
He declined to say how much Kazakhstan owed RAO Yedinaya Energeticheskaya Sistema Rossii (UES).
Kazakhstan will also offer UES 30 percent of the LEP-1 power line running from Siberia to the Urals across northern Kazakhstan as part of the deal.
UES said in August it had cut off supplies to Kazakhstan because of unpaid bills amounting to nearly $500 million.
UES President Anatoly Dyakov said then the company had suggested that Kazakhstan sell UES the Ekibastuz power station and part of a coal basin.
Ekibastuz is in the north-east of the central Asian country, and closer to Russia's Siberian centres of Omsk and Novosibirsk than to the Kazakh capital Almaty.
Ryaskov said Kazakhstan's state-owned coal company Ekibastuzkomir had already transferred its Severny (Northern) coalmine to UES's AO Sverdlovenergo unit in lieu of debts.
Kazakhstan's state privatisation committee valued the field at 1.15 billion tenge ($16.49 million).
Under the terms of the transfer, Sverdlovenergo must invest at least $89.7 million in the mine, pay royalties on coal produced and pay off the mine's debts and wage arrears.
Production at the mine has fallen to 10 million tonnes a year from a recent peak of 22 million tonnes.
